post_context: The latency of COVID-19 infection is biologically realistic due to an incubation period as long as 14 days; newly infected individuals may not be infectious while the virus is incubating in the body. Here we distinguish between the latent period, which is the time from infection to becoming infectious, and the incubation period, which is the time from infection to the onset of clinical symptoms like fever and coughing in COVID-19. In the case of SARS, individuals become infectious two days after symptoms begin, making the latent period longer than the incubation period. Evidence suggests that individuals with COVID-19 can be infectious before showing symptoms, but the length of the latent period is not well understood. The SEIR model is more biologically realistic than the SIR model, but it requires two extra parameters: the latent period and initial latent population. Transfer diagrams for both models can be seen in Fig. 1, while details of all model parameters are provided in Table 1 and Table 2. Both models assume that deaths in the S, E, and I compartments are negligible during the period of model predictions (4 months). Our model calibration uses newly confirmed case data, matching the rI term in both models, so the death term in the R compartment does not affect fitting. It is important to distinguish between the latent period, which is the time from infection to becoming infectious, and the incubation period, which is the time from infection to the appearance of symptoms like fever and coughing. In comparison to the SIR model, the SEIR model is more biologically realistic but requires additional parameters such as the latent period and initial latent population. The models are represented in transfer diagrams in Figure 1, with further details of the parameters in Tables 1 and 2. A key assumption in both models is that deaths in the S, E, and I compartments are negligible during the prediction period of 4 months. The differential equations for each model are provided, and model calibration is done using newly confirmed case data. The death term in the R compartment does not impact the model fitting process.

Following the announcement by the mayor of Hubei, China on January 23 that 5 million people had left the city by that date, we estimated the total population in Hubei, China on January 22 to be 6 million. Posterior distributions for estimated parameters were generated using the affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, with best-fit values and 95% credible intervals presented in Tables 1 and 2 for the SIR and SEIR models, respectively. Comparing the calibration results, the corrected Akaike Information Criterion was found to be 174 for the SIR model and 186 for the SEIR model, indicating a significant loss of information when using the latter. Future investigation will thus focus on the SIR model. Additionally, a linkage between the transmission rate b and diagnosis rate r was observed, as depicted in Fig. 2.

author: enrique
pre_context: Data from various sources, including technical, surveillance, and administrative data, as well as published literature, can be utilized for model calibration. However, this can be challenging during outbreaks of unknown pathogens such as SARS in 2003 and the current COVID-19. Alternatively, improving inference methods and model fitting algorithms can help narrow down wide confidence or credible intervals. Our fitting procedure, which employed Bayesian inference and an affine invariant ensemble Markov chain Monte Carlo algorithm, successfully achieved this aim. The baseline predictions for Beijing, including prediction intervals generated through random sampling of the posterior distribution, are based on data from newly confirmed cases reported from January 21 to February 4, 2020. These predictions provide insights into the hypothetical epidemic in Beijing if additional control measures were not implemented after February 7. Figures 4(a) and (b) display the distributions of the projected peak time and estimated values of the control reproduction number Rc for Beijing.4 (c), we show the projected time course of newly confirmed cases in Beijing together with its 95% prediction interval. The fit of our model predictions and the newly-confirmed case data is shown for the period between January 21 to February 4 in Fig. 4 (d). Based on these projections, if the more restrictive control measures after February 7 in the city were not implemented, the most likely peak time would have occurred on February 25, 2020, with the 95% credible interval from February 22 - March 5.
post_context: with the first quantile 1.414 and the third quantile 1.979. According to our estimates, if strict quarantine measures are not implemented after February 7, the number of peak cases would likely reach around 120,000, and the Beijing epidemic would not be resolved until May 2020.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: In PLOS Computational Biology, Covasim is introduced as an agent-based model that simulates COVID-19 dynamics and interventions. The model incorporates varying recovery times for individuals with different levels of symptoms, with a higher probability of death for critical cases, particularly among older individuals. Transmission of the virus occurs with a probability β whenever a susceptible individual encounters an infectious individual. In a well-mixed population with an average of 20 contacts per day, a value of β = 0.016 corresponds to a doubling time of 4-6 days and an R0 of approximately 2.2-2.7. This value was chosen based on data from Washington and Oregon states.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households,
post_context: , and 0.005 for the community.These ratios were chosen to align with previous research on time-use surveys and known types of infections. When considering the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population, the values of 10:2:2:1 were selected to achieve a weighted mean close to this default value. In the absence of interventions, transmission events are estimated to occur at approximately 30% in households, 25% at workplaces, 15% at schools, and 30% in the community. Interventions, such as physical distancing, can impact the value of β. Individual infectiousness can vary based on factors such as disease severity and time spent in each disease state. Viral load, which affects infectivity, is modeled to have an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. The default viral load is based on a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape parameter 0.45, consistent with international estimates and data from specific locations. Daily viral load is used to adjust the per-contact transmission probability, with representative individuals' viral loads shown in Fig 2.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context:
The duration of COVID-19 symptoms and viral shedding can vary widely, with durations increasing based on the severity of the illness. In our model, we account for this variability by assigning different recovery times for asymptomatic, mild, and severe cases, as outlined in Table 1. Non-critical cases are assumed to recover, while critical cases may recover or result in death, with the likelihood of death increasing with age (Table 2).

Transmission of the virus occurs when a susceptible individual comes into contact with an infectious person, with a probability of transmission denoted as β. In a well-mixed population with an average of 20 daily contacts per person, a β value of 0.016 corresponds to a doubling time of 4-6 days and an R0 of approximately 2.2-2.7. The exact R0 value can vary depending on factors such as population size and age structure. The default β value of 0.016 in Covasim was determined through calibration to data from Washington and Oregon states.However, this default value is too low for high-transmission contexts such as New York City or Lombardy [51], and may be too high for low-transmission contexts such as India's first wave [52]. Hence, this parameter must be calibrated by the user to match local epidemic data, as described in Section 2.6.8. If realistic network structure (i.e., households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts) is included, the value of β depends on the contact type. Default transmission probabilities are roughly 0.050 per contact per day for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and
post_context: .These weightings were chosen to align with time-use surveys and studies of infections with known contact types, aiming for a weighted mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population. When considering the default number of contacts in each layer, age-based susceptibility, and other factors, transmission events without interventions are estimated to be roughly 30% via households, 25% via workplaces, 15% via schools, and 30% via the community. Interventions like physical distancing can alter the value of β. Individual infectiousness is allowed to vary based on differences in viral load, with studies suggesting that viral load peaks around symptom onset and then decreases over time. This model includes two stages of viral load: a high early stage lasting up to 4 days, with the high stage set to twice the low stage. The daily viral load is adjusted to influence the per-contact transmission probability (β) for each individual. The default viral load for each agent is determined by a negative binomial distribution with a mean of 1.0 and shape parameter of 0.45. Viral loads for individuals with default parameters can be seen in Fig 2. Symptomatic, presymptomatic, and asymptomatic transmissions are all considered in this model.

author: enrique
pre_context: Therefore, the parameter β should be adjusted by the user to align with local epidemic data, as outlined in Section 2.6.8. When incorporating a realistic network structure, such as households, schools, workplaces, and community contacts, the value of β will vary based on the type of contact. Default transmission probabilities are around 0.050 for households, 0.010 for workplaces and schools, and 0.005 for the community. These values are chosen to be consistent with time-use surveys and previous studies, resulting in a weighted mean close to the default β value of 0.016 for a well-mixed population. When considering the default number of contacts in each layer, age-based susceptibility, and other factors, transmission events are approximately distributed as follows in the absence of interventions: 30% via households, 25% via workplaces, 15% via schools, and 30% via the community. The value of β can be adjusted by interventions like physical distancing. Additionally, individuals can vary in disease severity, time spent in each disease state, and infectivity levels, which are modeled based on individual viral load. Several studies have found that viral load is highest around or slightly before symptom onset, and then falls monotonically [54– 58]. As a simple approximation to this viral time course, we model two stages of viral load: an early high stage followed by a longer low stage. By default, we set the viral load of the high stage to be twice as high as the low stage and to last for either 30% of the infectious duration or 4 days, whichever is shorter. The default viral load for each agent is drawn from a negative binomial distribution with mean 1.0 and shape
post_context:
, which was the value most consistent with both international estimates [59,60] and fits to data in Washington state.

The per-contact transmission probability (β) for an individual is adjusted based on their daily viral load. Figure 2 displays viral loads for a sample of individuals with default parameter values. The proportions of transmissions by asymptomatic, presymptomatic, and symptomatic individuals can vary by location, with estimated numbers for Seattle provided in [25]. It is uncertain whether transmissibility is impacted by the presence of symptoms in the infectious person [55]. While we assume that it is not, there is a parameter that can be adjusted based on specific modeling needs or circumstances. Some studies have suggested much lower rates of infectiousness for asymptomatic individuals [61].
